articles.headline: Nielsen Plays Catch-Up as Streaming Era Wreaks Havoc on TV Raters
articles.snippet: Nielsen executives say that they have heard the complaints of TV and ad executives and are ready to track the many ways people consume media. But skeptics abound.
articles.abstract: Nielsen executives say that they have heard the complaints of TV and ad executives and are ready to track the many ways people consume media. But skeptics abound.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dennis Cheatham said he felt as if he were receiving a message from the past last May when a package arrived in the mail from Nielsen asking him to participate in the survey that for decades has detailed the television viewing habits of Americans.

articles.headline: Finding Common Political Ground on Poverty
articles.snippet: In an unlikely meeting of the minds, scholars from the left and the right managed to craft a compelling set of recommendations, despite their differences.
articles.abstract: In an unlikely meeting of the minds, scholars from the left and the right managed to craft a compelling set of recommendations, despite their differences.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you have been paying any attention to America’s paralyzed politics, you are not going to believe this.

articles.headline: ChemChina Is Close to a Deal to Buy Syngenta
articles.snippet: If completed, an acquisition of Syngenta, a Swiss agricultural and chemical giant, would be the largest by a Chinese company of a foreign company.
articles.abstract: If completed, an acquisition of Syngenta, a Swiss agricultural and chemical giant, would be the largest by a Chinese company of a foreign company.
articles.lead_paragraph: China is on the verge of its biggest ever foreign deal — and another possible political storm.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Rivals Look to New Hampshire for a Shot at Breaking Donald Trump’s Stride
articles.snippet: The Republican establishment closes ranks around a smaller number of candidates, but can Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio build on their Iowa momentum?
articles.abstract: The Republican establishment closes ranks around a smaller number of candidates, but can Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio build on their Iowa momentum?
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Emboldened by Donald J. Trump’s defeat in the Iowa caucuses, conservative leaders and rival candidates for the Republican presidential nomination began to challenge him aggressively in New Hampshire on Tuesday, aiming to cut into his wide lead here and perhaps even to embarrass him by denying him victory in a second consecutive state.

articles.headline: Martin Shkreli All but Gloated Over Huge Drug Price Increases, Memos Show
articles.snippet: Documents released by a congressional panel show that Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Turing Pharmaceuticals, Mr. Shkreli’s former company, sometimes raised prices as much as fiftyfold.
articles.abstract: Documents released by a congressional panel show that Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Turing Pharmaceuticals, Mr. Shkreli’s former company, sometimes raised prices as much as fiftyfold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli anticipated huge profits from raising the price of a decades-old drug for an infectious disease, belying any notion that helping patients was foremost in his mind, according to information released by congressional investigators on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Taliban Gun Down 10-Year-Old Militia Hero in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The former child soldier, Wasil Ahmad, was killed near his family’s home less than six months after he had fought to end a Taliban siege and was publicly — and illegally — celebrated.
articles.abstract: The former child soldier, Wasil Ahmad, was killed near his family’s home less than six months after he had fought to end a Taliban siege and was publicly — and illegally — celebrated.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government declared Wasil Ahmad a hero for leading a militia’s defense against a Taliban siege last year, parading him in front of cameras in a borrowed police uniform too big for him. On Monday, the Taliban triumphantly announced that they had assassinated him with two bullets to the head.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Taimoor Shah

articles.headline: Marissa Mayer Sets Yahoo on Streamlined Course
articles.snippet: Facing investor demands for action, Yahoo said it would lay off workers and explore possibilities that include sale of some assets.
articles.abstract: Facing investor demands for action, Yahoo said it would lay off workers and explore possibilities that include sale of some assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo is moving full speed ahead — in every direction.

articles.headline: Uber Drivers and Others in the Gig Economy Take a Stand
articles.snippet: As the online gig economy grows, workers are beginning to band together to secure what they see as fairer treatment from companies that make them feel more like employees than contractors.
articles.abstract: As the online gig economy grows, workers are beginning to band together to secure what they see as fairer treatment from companies that make them feel more like employees than contractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last September, Dallas-area drivers for UberBlack, the company’s high-end car service, received an email informing them that they would be expected to start picking up passengers on UberX, its low-cost option.

articles.headline: Marco Rubio Campaign Dispatches Its Army and New Lines of Attack
articles.snippet: Senator Marco Rubio’s campaign appears to be leaving little to chance in New Hampshire, aware that a lackluster result would greatly diminish him as he hopes to consolidate Republican support.
articles.abstract: Senator Marco Rubio’s campaign appears to be leaving little to chance in New Hampshire, aware that a lackluster result would greatly diminish him as he hopes to consolidate Republican support.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida landed here at 2 a.m. on Tuesday, bleary but beaming from a surprisingly strong showing in Iowa, and confronted growing expectations from his party’s establishment that he may be the best equipped to unite Republicans.

articles.headline: ChemChina Deal for Syngenta Reflects Drive to Meet Food Needs
articles.snippet: The transaction would be the largest acquisition of a foreign company by a Chinese firm and the latest in a string of deals by ChemChina.
articles.abstract: The transaction would be the largest acquisition of a foreign company by a Chinese firm and the latest in a string of deals by ChemChina.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s biggest pork producer and a major agricultural commodities trader have been among China’s prized acquisitions in recent years.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson, Chad Bray and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: Obama, in Mosque Visit, Denounces Anti-Muslim Bias
articles.snippet: The president used his first visit to a mosque in the United States since taking office to counter hostility to Islam.
articles.abstract: The president used his first visit to a mosque in the United States since taking office to counter hostility to Islam.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday embraced Muslims in the United States as part of “one American family” and implicitly criticized the Republican presidential candidates in a warning to citizens to not be “bystanders to bigotry.”

articles.headline: Dropbox May Not Be LeBron James, but It Is Still in the Game
articles.snippet: As the markets for funding tech start-ups cool, companies like Dropbox, which once had a $10 billion valuation, are confronting their outsize dreams of yesteryear.
articles.abstract: As the markets for funding tech start-ups cool, companies like Dropbox, which once had a $10 billion valuation, are confronting their outsize dreams of yesteryear.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are no obvious signs of distress at the lavish San Francisco headquarters of the cloud storage company Dropbox, where on any given day, its hallways bustle with upbeat, well-compensated tech workers enjoying the customary trappings of start-up life. Dropbox is not laying off workers or shrinking; it hired nearly 500 people last year, 75 since the start of this year, and it plans to soon move into a sprawling, custom-designed office building for which it has signed a long-term lease.
